awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Research Experiences for Teachers in Big Data and Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award creates a new Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site focused on Big Data and data science at the University of Louisville. Each summer, ten high school Science/Technology/Engineering/Mathematics (STEM) teachers will participate in research activities with faculty in labs at the University of Louisville.  The teachers will be recruited from Jefferson County Public Schools and the Ohio Valley Education Consortium.  Teachers in this site will apply fundamental data science techniques and learn Big Data principles while investigating real world problems with social relevance. The fast pace of low-cost technological innovation and data-centered operations have led to an explosion of data that can be used to solve problems and provide new insights for the future. This includes projects involving areas such as human welfare, healthcare, smart cities, and robotics. The participating teachers will translate their research experiences and knowledge into classroom practice by developing instructional modules and course materials that they will introduce in their classrooms and share with other teachers in their school districts. These activities all contribute to the formation of a community of practice in partnership with the University of Louisville faculty mentors that has the potential to significantly enhance STEM education in the participating school districts.

RET Site participants will participate in cutting-edge research projects with state-of-the-art data science tools and techniques. The RET Site features a unique combination of faculty mentors from the Department of Computer Engineering and Computer Science who have experience in both hardware and software, which is a synergistic combination in the field of Big Data.  The goals include: providing  quality research experiences in Big Data and data science for the high school teachers; strengthening the connection between the computing faculty and the school districts;  enhancing high school teachers' understanding of engineering research design and the principles of Big Data;  enhancing high school teachers' abilities to teach engineering and computer science concepts in a compelling way; and preparing engineering graduate students and university faculty to assist and support the high school teachers and their students. As Big Data permeates all sectors of society, Big Data problems often arise in diverse disciplines, not just the computing field.  The data-enabled approach is revolutionizing the way scientists and engineers in many fields practice, understand, and make discoveries.  Thus, Big Data can impact all STEM subjects and may become fundamental to a quality high school STEM education.  This project will help develop a core group of teachers who can bring Big Data principles and methods into their classrooms and excite high school students about the potential of Big Data and data science and its relevance to many possible career paths of the future.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Experience for Teachers (RET) site supported high school teachers in integrating computational thinking and engineering design into STEM classes, with a focus on Big Data applications. Teachers participated in immersive research experiences with experts in computer science and engineering, developing skills in data-driven analysis and predictive algorithms. These experiences equipped teachers to introduce computational thinking concepts in their classrooms, fostering skills relevant to real-world issues from healthcare to environmental science.

The RET project succeeded in advancing teachers’ understanding of Big Data and computational methods, enhancing high school STEM curricula, and strengthening connections between universities and local school districts. So far, 20 teachers have completed the program, reaching thousands of students with these new insights. In alignment with its mission to broaden participation, the program recruited teachers from diverse backgrounds and underrepresented groups, sharing its outcomes on platforms like TeachEngineering and an online resource hub for educators.

The RET program achieved key outcomes across teacher training, curriculum development, conference presentations, and community engagement. Teachers and participating faculty presented their research at national events, including the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) and NSF RET Virtual Poster Sessions, with topics ranging from machine learning to explainable AI and large language models. These experiences improved teachers' coding skills and their understanding of advanced AI concepts, enabling them to bring these insights directly into the classroom.

Teachers from diverse educational backgrounds participated, creating a broad impact across schools and communities. Evaluations through surveys and interviews showed high teacher satisfaction, with most planning to continue using the developed curricula. Collaborative efforts extended to local community leaders and interdisciplinary university groups, promoting the program’s success and encouraging future outreach. Teachers benefitted from mentorship and networking opportunities that supported their professional development and expanded the reach of data science education.

The teachers were mentored to develop innovative curricula that introduced data science and machine learning topics across subjects as diverse as biology, geometry, public health, and even weightlifting. Students engaged in hands-on projects, analyzing personal data, and discussing the ethical dimensions of AI, making learning experiential and relevant to their lives. Some teachers also established enrichment programs, such as coding clubs, to provide further engagement opportunities for students interested in computational thinking.

Overall, the RET project addressed the gap in computational thinking education by aligning with national standards to enhance critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Through its inclusive approach, the RET site inspired the next generation in data science, helping bridge educational divides and expand computational skills across disciplines.
